properties.media:imagetext:
October 15, 1947
En route Buenos Aires - Santiego
Dear Family:
We left Buenos Aires at 10:15 a.m., circled the new, nearly con-
pleted airport (which is to be one of the finest in the world),
traced
for a moment the super highway which leads to Buenos Aires, and then
headed west.
The first three and a half hours (about seven hundred
miles), our flight was across a flat plane checkerboarded with cultivated
fields resembling our western states of Kansas or Nebreska.
Now as I
write, we are over rougher country with an occasional small range of
hills.
In the distance many miles ahead loom the snow-capped Andes
shining white in a cloudless sky.
One hour later, and now we're over.
The scenic grandeur is far
beyond my apacity to describe.
We took the northern pass because both
the central and the southern were closed in by snow storms.
Now sliding
down the Pacific side, we are turning south to approach Santiago.
Our
pilot takes us down through the clouds to land at Santiago.
We took a
drive around the city and called on the Chinese ambassador for tea.
He
is a most charming host - Dr. Wu, whom I had known in China many years
ago and crossed the Pacific with from Shanghai last August.
We had dinner with the Panagra senior representative in Chile, Mr.
Carlos Bronson, who told us that his father was & Swedish captain who
married his mother - a Chilean - after a whirlwind courtship of four
days.
Bronson is typical of the people who make up the population of
metropoliten
Chile.
Thursday, October l6th, turned up with low visibility and plenty
of rain; also
it was very
cold.
We ventured out after the rain had let
up and bought some records of Chilean music we had heard the night
before.
Our hotel - the Carrera - is modern in every respect, but the
hot water is on only from 7:00 to 10:00 a.m. and there is no heat--all
because the Chilean miners are on strike and will produce no coal.
The
President made a bid for Communist support in the last election, and
then after he got in office became more conservative.
Unlike his counter-
part in England, he told the Chileans that prosperity could be enjoyed
only if the people went to work.
The rain and low visibility caused a twenty-four hour delay in our
schedule, so we decided to get a good rest after a pretty strenuous trip.
We made the rounds of the shopping distriet without seeing anything we
really wanted.
The shops looked a lot like Fowlers in Glens Falls.
We
had ten with Mrs. Sidney Lafoon's brother-in-law, who is in the U. S.
Embassy, and then I went to bed in order to get werm.
properties.wof:name: correspondence: Harold M. Bixby, family circular letter
